Home Movies Movie Features Chris Pine Is Right, Star Trek Isn't Marvel - But Then How Can It Survive in Theaters?    Chris Pine Is Right, Star Trek Isn't Marvel - But Then How Can It Survive in Theaters?  By Robert Vaux Published 22 hours ago     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email   Star Trek has always aimed for more personal movies and lowered sights at the box office. Changing that could be a mistake.                 Actor Chris Pine made waves recently when speaking to Deadline magazine about his return to the Star Trek franchise. He lamented the studio’s push for chasing the kind of billion-dollar box office figures routinely enjoyed by the likes of Star Wars or the Marvel Cinematic Universe. It wasn't necessarily a criticism. Rather, he simply noted that Star Trek is a different entity than either of those franchises and requires a different approach. He’s not wrong. Beyond their respective success and a loosely shared genre, they have less in common than it may seem.  That’s especially true for theatrical films, which Pine’s Kelvinverse has been the caretaker of for Star Trek since 2009, and which are undergoing a radical, perhaps permanent change. Star Trek isn’t necessarily the best fit for theaters, owing both to its very dedicated fan base and its origins in television rather than film. Trying to match the MCU or Star Wars for sheer box office figures won’t work. More importantly, it won’t be good for Star Trek. RELATED: Chris Pine Says Star Trek Shouldn't Compete With Marvel's 'Billion-Dollar' Movies                 Franchises are rapidly becoming the best way to stay competitive in Hollywood. The unparalleled success of the MCU and continued viability of Star Wars on the big screen have proven it, and along with DC, Star Trek and perhaps James Bond, they constitute the biggest and most durable examples currently on the market. That’s made them seemingly impervious to the decline in theatrical attendance. Spider-Man: No Way Home and The Batman have both rung up impressive box office figures in the face of a post-COVID environment. Similarly, Star Wars released one of the last blockbusters before the pandemic began with Star Wars: Episode IX – The Rise of Skywalker.  The Kelvinverse is Star Trek’s natural response to that. When the Star Trek movie reboot first arrived in 2009, the franchise had laid fallow for several years and was in danger of closing up shop. The trilogy proved successful – as well as providing Leonard Nimoy’s final onscreen appearances as Mr. Spock – and 2016’s Star Trek Beyond passed the baton to Star Trek: Discovery, which premiered a year later. If the franchise wants to return to big-screen films, the Kelvinverse is clearly the most reliable means to do so. And yet, Pine’s words suggest that setting the bar too high goes against the things that make Star Trek so appealing to the fans. Star Trek Beyond was labeled a box office underperformer, despite a healthy $340 million worldwide gross against a $180 million budget. That’s less than half of No Way Home’s take, and yet the changes required to keep pace with that amount would end up destroying the results rather than improving them. The franchise has had to learn that the hard way.  RELATED: Star Trek: The Motion Picture Remaster Reforges the Movie’s Legacy                 Star Wars and the MCU are both cinematic creations: born on the big screen and readily adapted to the kinds of storytelling that feature films tell exceptionally well. Both include heaping amounts of spectacle as part of their formula and stress the benefits of viewing their effects-laden action scenes on the biggest screen one can find. As cinema attendance has dropped, both shifted to television – and found success there, particularly the various Disney+ streaming shows – but they remain rooted in movie theater sensibilities. Star Trek approached things from the opposite direction. It began on television, and while it aimed for high-end effects and a grand scope, its storytelling was still crafted for the small screen. That meant an emphasis on individuals and single circumstances rather than the larger sweeping epics that other franchises aimed for.  That caused the franchise considerable problems when it first made the leap to the big screen. Star Trek: The Motion Picture underperformed at the box office and was rightfully criticized for losing track of the crew amid all the spectacle. That happened in part because it was pursuing Star Wars: Episode IV – A New Hope, which had shattered recorded two years earlier but whose operatic space fantasy began with the big screen in mind. In order to thrive in the multiplexes, Star Trek had to lower its sights. Star Trek II: The Wrath of Khan cut its budget severely – down to $11 million, which was less than a third of the first film’s expenses – but made only slightly less money. More importantly, it kept the focus on the actors, who were cheaper than effects, and Trek fans responded accordingly. That formula has worked for the remainder of the franchise’s big-screen films, but the returns have always been similar. 2009’s Star Trek remains the highest-grossing Trek movie, with $257 million in domestic receipts.  To push past that in an effort to essentially double the gross would be a disastrous move. The Motion Picture discovered that to its detriment, and the franchise learned those lessons well. The impact of COVID on movie theater attendance has only enhanced those conditions, such that expecting Star Trek to perform on a heretofore unseen level misses both the history and the key appeal that made it a success in the first place. In the meantime, it’s thriving on streaming services as never before, with five successful series currently in production and more on the way. That’s the screen it was built for, and while the Kelvinverse can continue to do well in movie theaters, it means seriously rethinking what success in that format means. Spider-Man: No Way Home and The Batman have both rung up impressive box office figures in the face of a post-COVID environment. Similarly, Star Wars released one of the last blockbusters before the pandemic began with Star Wars: Episode IX – The Rise of Skywalker.  The Kelvinverse is Star Trek’s natural response to that. When the Star Trek movie reboot first arrived in 2009, the franchise had laid fallow for several years and was in danger of closing up shop. The trilogy proved successful – as well as providing Leonard Nimoy’s final onscreen appearances as Mr. Spock – and 2016’s Star Trek Beyond passed the baton to Star Trek: Discovery, which premiered a year later. If the franchise wants to return to big-screen films, the Kelvinverse is clearly the most reliable means to do so. And yet, Pine’s words suggest that setting the bar too high goes against the things that make Star Trek so appealing to the fans. Star Trek Beyond was labeled a box office underperformer, despite a healthy $340 million worldwide gross against a $180 million budget. That’s less than half of No Way Home’s take, and yet the changes required to keep pace with that amount would end up destroying the results rather than improving them. The franchise has had to learn that the hard way.  RELATED: Star Trek: The Motion Picture Remaster Reforges the Movie’s Legacy                 Star Wars and the MCU are both cinematic creations: born on the big screen and readily adapted to the kinds of storytelling that feature films tell exceptionally well. Both include heaping amounts of spectacle as part of their formula and stress the benefits of viewing their effects-laden action scenes on the biggest screen one can find. As cinema attendance has dropped, both shifted to television – and found success there, particularly the various Disney+ streaming shows – but they remain rooted in movie theater sensibilities. Star Trek approached things from the opposite direction. It began on television, and while it aimed for high-end effects and a grand scope, its storytelling was still crafted for the small screen. That meant an emphasis on individuals and single circumstances rather than the larger sweeping epics that other franchises aimed for.  That caused the franchise considerable problems when it first made the leap to the big screen. Star Trek: The Motion Picture underperformed at the box office and was rightfully criticized for losing track of the crew amid all the spectacle. That happened in part because it was pursuing Star Wars: Episode IV – A New Hope, which had shattered recorded two years earlier but whose operatic space fantasy began with the big screen in mind. In order to thrive in the multiplexes, Star Trek had to lower its sights. Star Trek II: The Wrath of Khan cut its budget severely – down to $11 million, which was less than a third of the first film’s expenses – but made only slightly less money. More importantly, it kept the focus on the actors, who were cheaper than effects, and Trek fans responded accordingly. That formula has worked for the remainder of the franchise’s big-screen films, but the returns have always been similar. 2009’s Star Trek remains the highest-grossing Trek movie, with $257 million in domestic receipts.  To push past that in an effort to essentially double the gross would be a disastrous move. The Motion Picture discovered that to its detriment, and the franchise learned those lessons well. The impact of COVID on movie theater attendance has only enhanced those conditions, such that expecting Star Trek to perform on a heretofore unseen level misses both the history and the key appeal that made it a success in the first place. In the meantime, it’s thriving on streaming services as never before, with five successful series currently in production and more on the way. That’s the screen it was built for, and while the Kelvinverse can continue to do well in movie theaters, it means seriously rethinking what success in that format means. Home Anime New City Hunter Movie Announced for Series’ 35th Anniversary    New City Hunter Movie Announced for Series’ 35th Anniversary  By Michael Lacerna Published 18 hours ago     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email   Tsukasa Hojo's classic detective manga will return to theaters with an all-new adventure, just in time for the anime's 35th anniversary.                 The classic Shonen Jump series City Hunter will return with a new movie.  The new animated film was announced with a short teaser trailer that shows series' protagonist, Ryo Saeba, who will once again be voiced by veteran voice actor Akira Kamiya, who portrayed the character in the original 1987 anime series. The trailer is set to the song "Get Wild" by Japanese new wave band TM Network. The song was previously used as the first ending theme for the classic anime. A premiere date was not announced for the movie, but the preview does state that the movie is being produced to coincide with the 35th anniversary of the anime's premiere, which will occur in 2023.  RELATED: A Guide to City Hunter, the Cult Crime Franchise    City Hunter tells the story of Ryo Saeba, who survived a plane crash in Central America as a young child and is raised as a guerilla soldier. After honing his skills through a lifetime of warfare, Saeba returns to Japan as an adult, where he decides to use his talents to make a living as a private detective. The series was created by writer and artist Tsukasa Hojo. Hojo's original manga was serialized in Weekly Shonen Jump from 1985–1991. The manga was one of the biggest hits of the era in Japan, and several publishers attempted to license the series for release in the West, but these plans were stalled after Hojo refused to allow his artwork to be flipped and insisted that it only be published in manga's standard right-to-left format, which would have been unfamiliar with readers outside of Asia at the time. The manga was finally released in English in the early 2000s.  RELATED: Shonen Jump Publisher Enters Gaming Industry with Shueisha Games Hojo's manga is also notable for the amount of times it has been adapted: the series was first brought to the screen with the previously mentioned 1987 anime adaptation, which was produced by legendary animation studio Sunrise (Mobile Suit Gundam, Cowboy Bebop). The anime series ended in 1991, but the series has release multiple movies in the years since, the most recent of which was 2019's City Hunter: The Movie - Shinjuku Private Eyes. A number of live-action adaptations based on the manga have also been produced, including a Korean drama, a Japanese TV series, and most notably, a Hong Kong martial arts movie starring Jackie Chan.  The original anime and its follow-up movies are available for streaming on Crunchyroll. https://www.cbr.com/vaults-west-of-sundo.Title: Vault's Vampire/Western West of Sundown #1 Sees Constance Fleeing a Civil War
Data: www.cbr.com                  CBR Exclusives   Comics   Comics News   Comic Features   Comic Previews   Comic Reviews     Movies    Movie News   Movie Features   Movie Reviews     TV    TV News   TV Features   TV Reviews   Wrestling     Anime   Gaming   Lists   Write For CBR   More   CBR Forums   Buyer's Guides   Nerd Culture   Find a Comic Shop       Follow Us   Follow CBR            Something New                    	Covering the hottest movie and TV topics that fans want. Home Comics Comic Book Reviews Vault's West of Sundown #1 Comic Review    Vault's West of Sundown #1 Comic Review  By Bella Wheaton Published 2 days ago     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email   Part vampire horror and part Western, West of Sundown #1 sets up an interesting premise but does little to add to established lore.                                    Vault's West of Sundown #1   Artist  Jim Terry    Colorist  Triona Farrell    Cover Artist  Tim Daniel, Aaron Campbell    Letterer  Crank!    Price  3.99    Publisher  Vault Comics    Release Date  2022-04-06    Writer  Tim Seeley, Aaron Campbell      DC Comics veterans Tim Seeley and Aaron Campbell have penned their own original story, an ambitious amalgam of vampire thriller, monster horror, and Old Western, debuting this week from Vault Comics. Besides its illustrious writing team, West of Sundown #1 is created by artist Jim Terry, with colors by Triona Farrell and letters by Crank!. The cover touts a vintage monster story, framed by expressionistic art, gorgeous enough that many people will be buying this comic based on the outward aesthetic alone.  West of Sundown #1 follows the unexpected and untimely waking of vampire Constance Der Abend midway through a civil war she had very much intended to sleep through. Stumbling across her resting place, Dooley O'Shaughnessy, a confederate soldier without a cause, jumps at the opportunity to bail out of the war and become a full-time vampire manservant. When an unfortunate twist of fate drives them out of their fashionable New York upper-crust life, the pair must return to Constance's homeland of New Mexico to a much-changed landscape teeming with threats and lurking monsters. RELATED: DC's Batman #122 Comic Review                 Seeley and Campbell have delivered an extremely functional prologue to their vampire Western, although largely devoid of the kind of flair or style expected from the intersection of two incredibly dramatic genres. The plot itself has admirable clarity, but there is very little wit or elegance to the dialogue, especially with such colorful characters to play with. The dynamic between Dooley and Constance is touching, arguably the most interesting and novel part of the whole comic. Their relationship, somewhere between maternal and benevolent god, feels authentic and has lots of room to grow. Disappointingly, West of Sundown #1 does little to add to or complicate existing vampire lore, dealing mostly in already overplayed stereotypes with a  pale, dark-haired rich socialite who feeds off only those who deserve it. The twist of Constance's homeland and its importance is a much-needed detail that makes the story infinitely more memorable. Perhaps West of Sundown is hoarding its best and most inventive ideas for later in the story, which would only suggest some problems with the first issue's pacing and judgment.  The art, all produced by Terry, presents some of the strongest moments of West of Sundown #1. His depiction of Constance is appropriately inhuman in her perfection. Frequently the humans appear monstrous in contrast to her, a fascinating subversion waiting to be experimented with. The expressionist style of the cover is scarcely visible in the comic itself, generally working in much more conventional lines, which adds to the clarity but detracts from the distinct mood the comic is trying to set. The two-page spreads are the most artistically ambitious moments of the issue, with smaller undefined panels looping around a centerpiece in a way that feels chaotic and miasmic in equal measure, to stunning results.  RELATED: Marvel's Spider-Punk #1 Comic Review Farrell's colors are understated, often softened and neutral even in intense moments. The sepia undertone sells the vintage angle, making the comic feel like it is moving through the lens of the past. However, it means that any expectations built from the gorgeous cover of an ethereal, experimental visual experience are disappointed, met instead with a more lifelike and pedestrian approach. The letters, courtesy of Crank!, add a huge amount of much-needed dimension to the dialogue. The sound effects are also very well considered. The choice to change up the lettering for Dooley's internal monologue does a great job of setting a tone for the comic's second half and communicating more about Dooley's personality.  West of Sundown #1 has all the ingredients to be a terrific horror/Western, but the debut issue lacks edge or bite. There are moments of visual flair or satisfying character development, but overall, it fails to shock or awe or deliver on the aesthetic hinted at by the cover art. The comic's conclusion promises that conflict is just around the corner, and this team has put together an intriguing enough premise to make the next installments worth investigating. With a professional foundation in corporate copywriting, they are following their passions and diversifying their creative portfolio into reviewing, poetry, critical essays, and working on their first feature film treatment. Guilty of being an undiluted and unironic lover of Found Family Tropes, horror-comedy, queer representation, occultism and the literary stylings of Grant Morrison. Can be found on Twitter (@i_j____) but almost definitely shouldn't be. Home Comics Comic Book Reviews Marvel's X-Force Annual #1 Comic Review    Marvel's X-Force Annual #1 Comic Review  By Sayantan Gayen Published 14 hours ago     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email   X-Force Annual #1 is a classic X-Force story complete with lurking threats and suspicious teammates that hits all the right notes.                                    X-Force Annual #1   Writer  Nadia Shammas    Artist  Rafael Pimentel, Carlos Lopez    Letterer  VC's Joe Caramagna    Publisher  Marvel Comics    Price  4.99    Release Date  2022-04-06      Since its inception, X-Force has been touted as the black ops X-Men team that is usually delegated to handle all kinds of dirty work. For tasks that the X-Men can't or won't deal with, X-Force and its ragtag collection of less than savory, violence-loving characters usually get the job done. In the current world order, where Krakoa has redefined mutants as a force in the Marvel universe, X-Force remains the same but feels different. Its biggest threats come from its own teammates, especially Beast, who has lately been showing a frivolous disregard for the lives of pretty much anyone. Written by Nadia Shammas with artwork from Rafael Pimentel and Carlos Lopez and lettering by VC's Joe Caramagna, X-Force Annual #1 tells a story that continues ongoing arcs while developing the shady and distrustful dynamic that saturates this team.  X-Force Annual #1 follows the current X-Force team of Wolverine, Domino, and Quire as they are sent out on a covert mission to deal with a potential superweapon by Beast. On paper, it seems like your standard X-Force mission: get in, take out some bad guys, stop the weapon, and get out. Intel suggests that the Orchis have managed to steal a shipment from Hellfire Trading. As the mission progresses, it becomes clear that things aren't what they appear to be. The team starts to feel like maybe Beast has led them into a trap, but it's not clear why. RELATED: Marvel's Devil's Reign #6 Comic Review                  Nadia Shammas has a good handle on how each character of this ensemble cast responds and reacts to each other and their world. She shows off her good grasp of X-Men history and writing chops by creating a tense, suspicious atmosphere. The occasional well-placed bit of humor brings some much-needed levity to the book, as well. A pure highlight of this issue is Beast and Emma’s conversation, which wonderfully showcases just how far gone the once-lovable blue boy has become. Emma asks some pointed questions, and Beast expertly "addresses" them, though the results of this conversation are something that the writer keeps close to her chest. Anticipation like this builds towards a feeling of dread and excitement in equal measure, leaving the reader wondering just what weaknesses Beast can exploit out of this situation.  Rafael Pimentel's art and Carlos Lopez's colors work well to bring this adventure to life. Each character is distinctly and instantly identifiable by their silhouettes and colors. Wolverine, in particular, is drawn as stocky and thick, harkening back to his original stature and energy, which is something a lot of recent iterations tend to forget. This is an X-Men book through and through in all its colorful, weird glory, with Pimentel and Lopez determined to make readers see that in every frame. Though there are some slight hiccups here and there with some awkward art and stiff character movement, the overall look of the book is still great.  RELATED: Marvel's Marauders #1 Comic Review                 In this ever-expanding story of "What will Beast do next?" X-Force Annual #1 manages to ask the more serious questions about Beast's motivations. A great setup scene with '90s action drives the story into a far more nefarious arc once it reaches its conclusion. Nadia Shammas carries forward the torch left by her predecessor, Benjamin Percy, and absolutely runs with it. Beast may not be evil per se, but his complete disregard for the individual lives of his teammates in his pursuit of the greater good is a worrying precedent, one that rightfully builds suspicion from his peers. What happens next remains to be seen, but X-Force Annual #1 stands as a testament to the spirit of fun and suspense that X-Men comics hold. https://www.cbr.com/kaguya-sama-fujiwara.Title: Fujiwara Is Kaguya-sama's Best, Worst & Most Important Character
Data: www.cbr.com                  CBR Exclusives   Comics   Comics News   Comic Features   Comic Previews   Comic Reviews     Movies    Movie News   Movie Features   Movie Reviews     TV    TV News   TV Features   TV Reviews   Wrestling     Anime   Gaming   Lists   Write For CBR   More   CBR Forums   Buyer's Guides   Nerd Culture   Find a Comic Shop       Follow Us   Follow CBR            Something New                    	Covering the hottest movie and TV topics that fans want. Home Anime Kaguya-sama: Fujiwara Is the Best, Worst, Most Annoying & Most Important Character    Kaguya-sama: Fujiwara Is the Best, Worst, Most Annoying & Most Important Character  By Ryan McCarthy Published 20 hours ago     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email   Student Council Secretary Fujiwara Chika is a jack of all trades when it comes to her bizarre role in Kaguya-sama: Love Is War.                 As far as Fujiwara Chika is concerned, she's the main character of Kaguya-sama: Love Is War. The Student Council Secretary is as loveable as she is unlikeable, and her delightfully inane shenanigans are outweighed only by the chaos and destruction she wreaks upon the Student Council Room every time she enters or exists in close proximity to it. She's the kind of character who viewers can't wait to see what she'll do next but also wish she would just go away. The paradox to end all paradoxes, Fujiwara is the best, worst, most annoying and most important character in a series that she goes to extraordinary lengths to make about herself.  In Fujiwara's defense, it's not like her fellow Student Council members are entirely well-adjusted either. Shinomiya Kaguya usually considers Fujiwara either sub-human garbage she'd prefer to set adrift at sea without a life jacket or her best friend, depending on whatever it is that Fujiwara has most recently said or done. Fujiwara often deserves Shinomiya's ire, but she also must be protected at all costs because the audience deserves to know whether or not Fujiwara is intentionally ruining the love war between Shinomiya and Shirogane. Fujiwara is either a diabolical genius or an unbiased force of nature whose lifeblood is the very chaos she ignites wherever she goes.  RELATED: Kaguya-sama: What's the Score Heading Into Season 3?          Fujiwara Is Kaguya-Sama's Best Character                 There's never a dull moment when Fujiwara is around. At any moment, she's liable to break out in a highly choreographed dance, suggest an overly-complicated game that she'll instantly start cheating at or show a seasoned ramen lover what a real connoisseur looks like. She's a good friend to Shirogane whenever he needs help with whatever new thing he's terrible at, and she undoubtedly adores Shinomiya. Fujiwara can't be pigeonholed because she's doing something different every episode, either showing off incredible intelligence and skill or an incredible lack thereof. She's a member of the Tabletop Game Club, the conductor for the morning singing of Shuchi'in Academy's anthem, a proud dog mom, an average volleyball player and an ace(ish) detective who can't whistle or read the room. The only thing that's predictable about her is her unpredictability, and it's her biggest strength as the series' most versatile character.          Fujiwara Is Also Love Is War's Worst Character                 The flip side to Fujiwara's versatility is that she's more of a plot device than a character. Need a funny joke to end an otherwise serious scene? Send in Fujiwara. Need someone for a lead character to confide in to further their own story? Fujiwara's the gal for the job. Ishigami has gotten his own episode devoted to his history and the challenges he's overcome, and even Hayasaka has had some sympathetic moments as Shinomiya's caretaker. Fujiwara, unfortunately, has never had any kind of character arc because her role is simply to cause madness and mayhem. She has never had a personal insecurity to overcome, an enemy to defeat or even a brief moment of self-reflection. Fujiwara is only here for a good time, and she doesn't accept criticism or responsibility, which would make her hard to root for if there was ever anything actually happening with her.  RELATED: Kaguya-sama: Love is War Season 3 to Premiere in US Theaters          Fujiwara Is The Series' Most Annoying Character                 Despite Fujiwara's best efforts, she is not the main character of Kaguya-sama: Love Is War -- in fact, she might actually be the villain. The battle between Shinomiya and Shirogane to get the other to confess their love is the driving force of the series, and Fujiwara is constantly derailing it. Shinomiya and Shirogane are possibly two of the most stubborn characters in anime, considering the entire premise of their show is based on how stubborn they are. On the rare occasion that one or both of them drop their guard and there's an opportunity for them to give up the act and be together, here comes Fujiwara to eat the food they're feeding each other or just kill the vibe in general. Once or twice could be chalked up to bad timing, but Fujiwara might just be the biggest reason that Shinomiya and Shirogane aren't a couple yet -- other than their own pride, of course.          Kaguya-sama: Love Is War Couldn't Survive Without Fujiwara                 Given that the whole point of the show is who's going to confess first, a confession can't happen at all until the end of the series, as without Shinomiya and Shirogane's battle, there's no story. This makes Fujiwara the most important character because her constant, exhausting, frustrating, childish, selfish and hilarious interruptions and love-blocking antics keep the series afloat. There should be exactly zero fans of Fujiwara Chika given the undesirable role of roadblock that she's forced to play in the series. That she's so loved despite this is a testament to the strength of her character, even if nothing about her ever makes sense -- because without her, the show wouldn't make sense either. You can find him complaining about Rise of Skywalker on Twitter as @RickeySpanish because even his Twitter handle is an American Dad reference.

Data: www.cbr.com                  CBR Exclusives   Comics   Comics News   Comic Features   Comic Previews   Comic Reviews     Movies    Movie News   Movie Features   Movie Reviews     TV    TV News   TV Features   TV Reviews   Wrestling     Anime   Gaming   Lists   Write For CBR   More   CBR Forums   Buyer's Guides   Nerd Culture   Find a Comic Shop       Follow Us   Follow CBR            Something New                    	Covering the hottest movie and TV topics that fans want. Home Anime Requiem of the Rose King: How to Get Started With the Anime & Manga    Requiem of the Rose King: How to Get Started With the Anime & Manga  By Timothy Donohoo Published 9 hours ago     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email   Requiem of the Rose King reimagines Shakespeare in a strangely beautiful way, and the anime has only now started as the manga has ended.                 Many works throughout the decades have adapted and re-imagined the writings of William Shakespeare, but perhaps none more so than Requiem of the Rose King. Combining two Shakespeare plays into one, the result is an entirely different story altogether. The original manga recently came to an end just as the anime began, with two versions of the very altered history now available.  History and literature buffs who think they know the story already are in for several surprises, while those who don't even like Shakespeare are sure to find something that they enjoy in the franchise. Here's more on what Requiem of the Rose King is about, as well as how to read and watch the different versions of it. RELATED: How to Get Started With K-On!          The Plot of Requiem of the Rose King                 Requiem of the Rose King loosely combines elements of William Shakespeare's Henry VI, Part 3 and Richard III, turning the War of the Roses completely on its head. In the story, the Houses of York and Lancaster battle over England, with the House of York losing its leader to a deadly enemy attack. Left in the wake of this loss is Richard III, the king's intersex son who identifies as male. Richard is hated and feared by many around him, including his own mother, all while spirits torture and subjugate him. Forced into an unlikely situation, Richard prepares to defend his house while dealing with external and internal threats.  RELATED: How to Get Started With Ouran High School Host Club          Where to Read the Requiem of the Rose King Manga                 Requiem of the Rose King began as a manga from Aya Kanno in October 2013, being published in the magazine Monthly Princess. The series ran for almost nine years, ending in early 2022. In the West, the series has been localized by Viz Media, with 14 of the 17 volumes having been released in English-speaking territories. The series has two spin-offs: King of Idol: Bara-Ō no Gakuen and Bara-Ō no Sōretsu: Gaiden. The former is a more humorous spin-off where the characters are in high school studying to become entertainers, while the latter focuses on events not shown in the main series. Since both of them only began in the last year, neither has yet been localized. The main series' manga can be purchased physically wherever manga is sold, including Walmart, Books-a-Million, Barnes & Noble and Amazon, while Kindle and Comixology carry the digital version.  RELATED: How to Get Started With Bakuman          Where to Watch the Requiem of the Rose King Anime                The anime adaptation of the series began airing in January 2022, just as the manga ended, although it was originally intended to come out in late 2021. Requiem of the Rose King was animated by J.C. Staff, a well-known studio whose recent works include the anime for How a Realist Hero Rebuilt the Kingdom as well as Is It Wrong to Pick Up Girls in a Dungeon?. The result is a series with beautiful, breathtaking art, befitting the nature of the characters. So far, 13 episodes have aired in Japan, with the show planned to air for two consecutive cours. The only way to watch the series in the West currently is through the Funimation streaming service. However, this service simulcast Requiem of the Rose King, so it's only available as a subtitled series and not dubbed. However, once the series has finished its run, a dub and physical releases will likely be on the way. https://www.cbr.com/hbo-max-you-brought-.Title: DC's Gay Aquaman Lands His Own HBO Max Series
Data: www.cbr.com                  CBR Exclusives   Comics   Comics News   Comic Features   Comic Previews   Comic Reviews     Movies    Movie News   Movie Features   Movie Reviews     TV    TV News   TV Features   TV Reviews   Wrestling     Anime   Gaming   Lists   Write For CBR   More   CBR Forums   Buyer's Guides   Nerd Culture   Find a Comic Shop       Follow Us   Follow CBR            Something New                    	Covering the hottest movie and TV topics that fans want. Home TV TV News DC's Gay Aquaman Lands His Own HBO Max Series    DC's Gay Aquaman Lands His Own HBO Max Series  By Noah Dominguez Published 11 hours ago     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email   HBO Max is developing a series based on the GLAAD Media Award-nominated graphic novel You Brought Me the Ocean, starring DC's second Aquaman.                 HBO Max is working on a new series starring DC's Jackson "Jake" Hyde, an openly gay comic book character who is perhaps best known as the second Aqualad -- and who recently became the second Aquaman.  According to Variety, HBO Max is currently developing a live-action adaptation of You Brought Me the Ocean, the GLAAD Media Award-nominated YA graphic novel written by Alex Sánchez, illustrated by Jul Maroh and lettered by Deron Bennett. The series will consist of hour-long episodes and is being described as a "dramedy." Charlize Theron, A.J. Dix, Beth Kono and Andrew Haas are attached as executive producers. RELATED: DC's New Young Justice Series Continues the Legacy of 'Phantoms' "The series will explore the life of Jackson 'Jake' Hyde, a gay teenager living in New Mexico," Variety explains. "All his life, he has had a strange attraction to the water and yearns to escape his desert surroundings for the ocean. As he explores his abilities, including breathing under and controlling water, he also finds himself falling in love with his classmate, high school swim captain Kenny Liu."  Created by Brandon Vietti, Greg Weisman and Phil Bourassa, the character of Kaldur'ahm (or "Kaldur" for short) first appeared in 2010, originating from the popular DC animated series Young Justice. Kaldur was created as a new version Aqualad, taking over for the original Aqualad, Garth, who was going by the name Tempest in the DC comic books at the time. Also in 2010, a slightly modified version of Kaldur named Jackson Hyde made his comic book debut as the new Aqualad in Brightest Day #4. RELATED: Young Justice: Why Every Episode Features the Number '16' In DC's comic book universe, Jackson has been depicted as openly gay post-Rebirth, whereas his Young Justice counterpart has been portrayed as bisexual. In 2020, DC published You Brought Me the Ocean under its DC Graphic Novels for Young Adults imprint, bringing Aqualad's sexuality to the forefront. The graphic novel focuses on yet another modified version of the character named Jake Hyde and his budding romance with Kenny Liu. You Brought Me the Ocean was nominated for Outstanding Comic Book at the 32nd GLAAD Media Awards in 2021.  It was also in 2021 that Jackson Hyde became the second in-continuity Aquaman, taking up the mantle in the six-issue limited series Aquaman: The Becoming. Jackson then teamed up with the original Aquaman, Arthur Curry, for a follow-up series, aptly titled Aquamen. KEEP READING: HBO Max Adapting Bendis & Sook's Legion of Super-Heroes as an Adult Animated Series Source: Variety                  Moon Knight's Mr. Knight Funko Pop! In 2020, DC published You Brought Me the Ocean under its DC Graphic Novels for Young Adults imprint, bringing Aqualad's sexuality to the forefront. The graphic novel focuses on yet another modified version of the character named Jake Hyde and his budding romance with Kenny Liu. You Brought Me the Ocean was nominated for Outstanding Comic Book at the 32nd GLAAD Media Awards in 2021.  It was also in 2021 that Jackson Hyde became the second in-continuity Aquaman, taking up the mantle in the six-issue limited series Aquaman: The Becoming. Jackson then teamed up with the original Aquaman, Arthur Curry, for a follow-up series, aptly titled Aquamen. KEEP READING: HBO Max Adapting Bendis & Sook's Legion of Super-Heroes as an Adult Animated Series Source: Variety                  Moon Knight's Mr. Knight Funko Pop! https://www.cbr.com/green-lantern-12-the.Title: Green Lantern #12 Includes an Unexpected and Perfect Jack Kirby Homage
Data: www.cbr.com                  CBR Exclusives   Comics   Comics News   Comic Features   Comic Previews   Comic Reviews     Movies    Movie News   Movie Features   Movie Reviews     TV    TV News   TV Features   TV Reviews   Wrestling     Anime   Gaming   Lists   Write For CBR   More   CBR Forums   Buyer's Guides   Nerd Culture   Find a Comic Shop       Follow Us   Follow CBR            Something New                    	Covering the hottest movie and TV topics that fans want. Home Comics Comic News Green Lantern #12 Includes an Unexpected and Perfect Jack Kirby Homage    Green Lantern #12 Includes an Unexpected and Perfect Jack Kirby Homage  By Noah Dominguez Published 6 hours ago     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email   DC's Green Lantern #12 features a perfect tribute to the late, great Jack Kirby.                 John Stewart comes face-to-face with a comic book legend in DC's Green Lantern #12 -- even if he doesn't realize it.  DC has provided CBR with an official preview for Green Lantern #12, which is set to hit comic shops on Tuesday, April 12 -- having been pushed back from its original solicited release date of March 1. The issue comes from writer Geoffrey Thorne, artists Tom Raney and Marco Santucci, colorist Mike Atiyeh and letterer Rob Leigh. It features a main cover by Bernard Chang and Alex Sinclair, as well as a variant cover by Alan Quah. RELATED: EXCLUSIVE: DC's Round Robin Round 2 Creative Teams and Expanded Descriptions, Revealed The preview itself sees John Stewart/Green Lantern meet The Source, the limitless energy from which all life in the universe emerged. The concept of The Source was created by legendary writer/artist Jack Kirby, first appearing in New Gods #1, cover-dated March 1971. Fittingly, for its Green Lantern appearance, The Source manifests itself as a suit-wearing man who bears an uncanny resemblance to the late, great Kirby.  Of course, The Source has manifested in other forms in the past. "Sometimes I'm a wall and a flaming hand," the entity says, referencing its 1971 debut. "Once, I was a turtle." However, the inspiration for this particular manifestation is undeniable. The scene in question even features a fair amount of Kirby Krackle, an artistic device innovated by The King himself. RELATED: DC Debuts a Robin-Styled Superboy to Celebrate Superman's Death and Legacy                                       GREEN LANTERN #12                           Written by GEOFFREY THORNE                                       Art by TOM RANEY and MARCO SANTUCCI                                       Cover by BERNARD CHANG                                       Variant cover by ALAN QUAH                                       $4.99 US | 40 pages | $5.99 US Variant (card stock)                                       ON SALE 3/1/22                                       As the dust settles after the battle with the Anti-Guardian, John Stewart, Jo Mullein, and the rest of the Corps pick up the pieces and adjust to their new status quo. The day might be saved, but there's still plenty of work to be done. Everything you know about Green Lanterns is about to change!                                                                                           This certainly isn't the first time the current Green Lantern title has referenced Kirby's New Gods, with December's issue #9 having brought the character of Esak back to the DC Universe following an extended absence. Written by Geoffrey Thorne, illustrated by Tom Raney and Marco Santucci, colored by Mike Atiyeh and lettered by Rob Leigh, Green Lantern #12 goes on sale April 12 from DC. He has also written for sites like WhatCulture and Gaming Access Weekly (formerly Gamer Assault Weekly), and holds a degree in mass communication. What will he do next? Stay tuned. RELATED: DC Debuts a Robin-Styled Superboy to Celebrate Superman's Death and Legacy                                       GREEN LANTERN #12                           Written by GEOFFREY THORNE                                       Art by TOM RANEY and MARCO SANTUCCI                                       Cover by BERNARD CHANG                                       Variant cover by ALAN QUAH                                       $4.99 US | 40 pages | $5.99 US Variant (card stock)                                       ON SALE 3/1/22                                       As the dust settles after the battle with the Anti-Guardian, John Stewart, Jo Mullein, and the rest of the Corps pick up the pieces and adjust to their new status quo. The day might be saved, but there's still plenty of work to be done. Everything you know about Green Lanterns is about to change!                                                                                           This certainly isn't the first time the current Green Lantern title has referenced Kirby's New Gods, with December's issue #9 having brought the character of Esak back to the DC Universe following an extended absence. Written by Geoffrey Thorne, illustrated by Tom Raney and Marco Santucci, colored by Mike Atiyeh and lettered by Rob Leigh, Green Lantern #12 goes on sale April 12 from DC. Home Anime Yashahime Season 2's Biggest Unanswered Questions    Yashahime Season 2's Biggest Unanswered Questions  By Caroline Ramsburg Published 22 hours ago     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email   Here are some of the most burning questions remaining in Yashahime after the wild conclusion to Season 2.                  The following contains spoilers for Season 2 of Yashahime: Princess Half-Demon, now streaming on Crunchyroll, Funimation, Animelab and Hulu.   With the recent conclusion of Yashahime Season 2, fans have been left with several questions surrounding the Great Dog Demon Family and the original cast of Inuyasha. After the Season 2 finale wrapped up the series' main plot arc with the death of Kirinmaru, the heroes seem happy and free of conflict at last.  While this peaceful and reflective season finale left many wondering if Season 2 will be the end of the entire series, there are still several unanswered questions for Yashahime to hopefully address in future seasons. RELATED: Yashahime Concludes Its Biggest Arc Yet With Death - and Happiness          Does Sesshomaru Love His Daughters?                At the end of Season 2, Towa and Setsuna reunite with their mother Rin to celebrate their recent victory. When Rin gifts her twin daughters fancy fabrics given to them by their father, the twins question his actions and parenting style. They ask Rin why Sesshōmaru didn't help them more when they were growing up -- and when they faced Zero and Kirinmaru.  After calling their father's love for them into question, Rin assures her daughters that he loves them and is relieved that they grew up to become strong on their own. Despite Sesshōmaru displaying tremendous character growth as he operated in the shadows to protect his family, the twins hope to uncover their kuudere father's true feelings. RELATED: The Best Isekai in Which the Main Character Returns Home          How Is Riku Still Alive?                 As the former horn of Kirinmaru, Riku has proven to have several lives in Yashahime. After suffering many fatal and near-fatal injuries, this mysterious character has always managed to return from the grave to shock fans. Toward the very end of Season 2, Riku is killed by Mr. Kirin within the Grim Butterfly. He says a tearful goodbye to Towa and confesses his love for her before seemingly dying for good.  However, when Towa's body is returned to her by Rion, many fans spotted a mysterious horn-shaped figure inside her body. In the Season 2 finale, Riku is resurrected and reappears to explain that he is no longer part of Kirinmaru -- and that he was revived by Rion and Kirinmaru's Kon and Haku. Setsuna questions how this is possible, as do many fans. RELATED: Yashahime Tackles the Morality of Humans and Demons          Why Didn't Sango and Miroku Raise Moroha?                 Since Yashahime began, many fans questioned the noticeable absence of the original Inuyasha cast. Despite Sango and Miroku being alive and well with their own family, they are surprisingly absent from Moroha's life. Kagome and Inuyasha instructed Hachi to take the baby Moroha to the Wolf Demon Tribe for protection instead of entrusting their two best friends with their daughter in their absence.  While they may have chosen Koga and the Wolf Demon Tribe for protection and the strength in numbers, Sango and Miroku have proven their own strength and capabilities time and time again. Not only were Sango and Miroku oddly absent from Moroha's life, but Shippo somehow failed to find Moroha despite her living nearby. RELATED: What Religion Do Anime Monks Like Inyuasha's Miroku Practice?          How Strong Is Shippo Now?                 During the time skip between Inuyasha and Yashahime, it's revealed that Shippo has become a respectable and powerful teacher at a fox-demon school. After spending most of Inuyasha training to become a full-fledged fox demon, he now has the 25th and highest rank in the demon promotions and spends most of his time preparing others for their own exams.  In his first appearance in the sequel, Shippo surprised fans by taking on the form of an elderly fox and a young man before returning to his more familiar younger form. After achieving the highest rank and learning advanced Fox Magic like "Up, Up, and Away", many fans are wondering just how powerful Shippo has become and what tricks he might reveal later in the series. RELATED: Should Moroha Have Been Yashahime's Main Character?          Which Twin is Stronger: Towa or Setsuna?                 Towa and Setsuna sparred several times throughout Yashahime when they were pitted against each other by their enemies or emotional outbursts. Given their unique strengths and weaknesses that cancel each other out, these battles typically ended it stalemates. Since the sisters wield different weapons and inherited different powers from their immensely powerful father, it's incredibly difficult to compare the two. While they are both inarguably strong as the daughters of the Great Beast King of the West, the series has never revealed who would ultimately win in an all-out fight between the two.                   After Its Satisfying Season 2 Finale, Does Yashahime Need a Season 3? Home Comics Comic Book Previews My Date With Monsters #5    My Date With Monsters #5  By Liam Nolan Published Mar 07, 2022     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email   AfterShock Comics presents a preview of My Date With Monsters #5, by Paul Tobin and Andy MacDonald.                     My Date With Monsters #5  Artist  Andy MacDonald  Colorist  DJ Chavis  Cover Artist  DJ Chavis, Andy MacDonald  Letterer  Taylor Esposito  Price  3.99  Publisher  AfterShock Comics  Release Date  2022-03-30  Writer  Paul Tobin     Risa and Genka meet at last, but it’s rather difficult to have love in the air when the air is so thoroughly stuffed with chaos and the blaring alarms of a major monster breakout! Plus, Risa uncovers the true secret of the nightmares, a secret that will rock the very foundations of her belief in this world, and the ones beyond. Meanwhile, Croak eats a lot of pests. Things are messy all over!                                                                                              Moon Knight's Mr. Knight Funko Pop! https://www.cbr.com/pokmon-cosplayer-fin.Title: Pokémon Cosplayer Finds Beauty in the Franchise's Trash(bag)
Data: www.cbr.com                  CBR Exclusives   Comics   Comics News   Comic Features   Comic Previews   Comic Reviews     Movies    Movie News   Movie Features   Movie Reviews     TV    TV News   TV Features   TV Reviews   Wrestling     Anime   Gaming   Lists   Write For CBR   More   CBR Forums   Buyer's Guides   Nerd Culture   Find a Comic Shop       Follow Us   Follow CBR            Something New                    	Covering the hottest movie and TV topics that fans want.                                      	All the latest gaming news, game reviews and trailers.                                      	A one-stop shop for all things video games.                                           Home Video Games Pokémon Cosplayer Finds Beauty in the Franchise's Trash(bag)    Pokémon Cosplayer Finds Beauty in the Franchise's Trash(bag)  By Hayley McCullough Published 16 hours ago     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email   Cosplayer Mink the Satyr shows off her incredible Trubbish costume, which transforms the monster's garbage aesthetic into pure elegant fashion.                        A talented fan has transformed the grubby Trash Bag Pokémon, Trubbish, into a creature of pure elegance and beauty.  Popular cosplayer and vtuber Mink the Satyr posted multiple pictures of her Trubbish-inspired costume to Twitter. The beautiful evening gown features delicate lace, billowing sleeves and a full skirt. The cosplayer also uploaded a much more comical version of the costume as an April Fool's joke. RELATED: Electrifying Pokémon Fan Art Reimagines a Legendary Monster as Mech    According to the various Pokédex entries for the monster, Trubbish is a fifth-generation Pokémon and a fusion of garbage bags, industrial waste and chemical agents. It belches toxic gas and has a tendency to follow individuals who litter around. Beyond the games, Trubbish has appeared several times in the greater Pokémon franchise, making minor appearances, for example, in the episodes "Crystal-Clear Sleuthing!" and "Love at First Twirl!" in Pokémon the Series: Sun & Moon.  There have been more recent developments in the Pokémon franchise than just beautiful cosplays. Most notably, two new games -- Pokémon Scarlet and Violet -- are scheduled to debut sometime late this year. These games will introduce fans to the ninth generation of Pokémon and many have already fallen in love with the new starters -- Fucecoco, Sprigatito and Quaxly. Scarlet and Violet will include the open-world gameplay style featured in Pokémon Legends: Arceus and showcase a Spain-inspired setting. RELATED: Study Finds Sonic the Hedgehog Is More Popular Than Pokémon  Moreover, the next batch of episodes for the Pokémon Master Journeys anime series are on their way. While the official premiere date is presently unknown, a teaser trailer and a new poster provide insight into upcoming story beats. These include Ash reuniting with his Greninja, Chloe competing in a contest with her Eevee and Goh encountering the legendary Pokémon Suicune (and possibly Mew as well). Pokémon Master Journeys is the twenty-fourth mainline anime series for the franchise; it premiered on Dec. 11, 2020, in Japan and in the United States on Sept. 10, 2021. An anime based on Pokémon Legends: Arceus has also been announced. While little information about the series has been released, it is expected to premiere online sometime in 2022. Arceus is also getting a special tie-in expansion for the Pokémon Trading Card Game. Astral Radiance will introduce a wealth of cards to the ever-expanding tabletop game and will usher in Radiant Pokémon, a brand-new mechanic. The expansion is scheduled to launch on May 27 and pre-orders are now available.  Several entries in the Pokémon franchise, including Pokémon Master Journeys, can be found and streamed on Netflix. Pokémon Legends: Arceus is now available exclusively for the Nintendo Switch. Source: Twitter                  Morbius Director Reveals How Pokémon Influenced the Film  Read Next     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email    Related Topics  Anime Video Games Pokemon     About The Author      Hayley McCullough                                     (438 Articles Published)     Hayley is a News Writer for CBR. In 2021, she earned her PhD in Communication & Rhetoric from Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute and currently works in the Department of Communication, Liberal Arts, and Social Sciences at New Mexico Tech. Her research examines the linguistic structure of storytelling and pop culture. She can often be found marathoning horror movies instead of sleeping, playing puzzle games, and reading a probably unhealthy amount of fanfiction. Home Video Games Pokémon Cosplayer Finds Beauty in the Franchise's Trash(bag)    Pokémon Cosplayer Finds Beauty in the Franchise's Trash(bag)  By Hayley McCullough Published 16 hours ago     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email   Cosplayer Mink the Satyr shows off her incredible Trubbish costume, which transforms the monster's garbage aesthetic into pure elegant fashion.                        A talented fan has transformed the grubby Trash Bag Pokémon, Trubbish, into a creature of pure elegance and beauty.  Popular cosplayer and vtuber Mink the Satyr posted multiple pictures of her Trubbish-inspired costume to Twitter. The beautiful evening gown features delicate lace, billowing sleeves and a full skirt. The cosplayer also uploaded a much more comical version of the costume as an April Fool's joke. RELATED: Electrifying Pokémon Fan Art Reimagines a Legendary Monster as Mech    According to the various Pokédex entries for the monster, Trubbish is a fifth-generation Pokémon and a fusion of garbage bags, industrial waste and chemical agents. It belches toxic gas and has a tendency to follow individuals who litter around. Beyond the games, Trubbish has appeared several times in the greater Pokémon franchise, making minor appearances, for example, in the episodes "Crystal-Clear Sleuthing!" and "Love at First Twirl!" in Pokémon the Series: Sun & Moon.  There have been more recent developments in the Pokémon franchise than just beautiful cosplays. Most notably, two new games -- Pokémon Scarlet and Violet -- are scheduled to debut sometime late this year. These games will introduce fans to the ninth generation of Pokémon and many have already fallen in love with the new starters -- Fucecoco, Sprigatito and Quaxly. Scarlet and Violet will include the open-world gameplay style featured in Pokémon Legends: Arceus and showcase a Spain-inspired setting. RELATED: Study Finds Sonic the Hedgehog Is More Popular Than Pokémon  Moreover, the next batch of episodes for the Pokémon Master Journeys anime series are on their way. While the official premiere date is presently unknown, a teaser trailer and a new poster provide insight into upcoming story beats. These include Ash reuniting with his Greninja, Chloe competing in a contest with her Eevee and Goh encountering the legendary Pokémon Suicune (and possibly Mew as well). Pokémon Master Journeys is the twenty-fourth mainline anime series for the franchise; it premiered on Dec. 11, 2020, in Japan and in the United States on Sept. 10, 2021. An anime based on Pokémon Legends: Arceus has also been announced. While little information about the series has been released, it is expected to premiere online sometime in 2022. Arceus is also getting a special tie-in expansion for the Pokémon Trading Card Game. Astral Radiance will introduce a wealth of cards to the ever-expanding tabletop game and will usher in Radiant Pokémon, a brand-new mechanic. The expansion is scheduled to launch on May 27 and pre-orders are now available.  Several entries in the Pokémon franchise, including Pokémon Master Journeys, can be found and streamed on Netflix. Pokémon Legends: Arceus is now available exclusively for the Nintendo Switch. Home Anime Sailor Moon Knight Fan Art Is the Ultimate Lunar Hero Crossover    Sailor Moon Knight Fan Art Is the Ultimate Lunar Hero Crossover  By Hayley McCullough Published 17 hours ago     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email   Sailor Moon dons the costume of Marvel's Moon Knight in a new piece of epic mashup fan art that celebrates both the anime and the new Disney+ series.                 One creative superhero fan has merged the magical worlds of Naoko Takeuchi's Sailor Moon and the Marvel Cinematic Universe's Moon Knight, creating "the crossover no one asked for."  The image, which was posted on Twitter by professional production designer Mingjue Helen Chen, depicts Usagi Tsukino/Sailor Moon donning a costume reminiscent of Marc Spector/Moon Knight's super suit. The long, white cape and Usagi's iconic blond hair flutter in the foreground, while a glowing crescent moon features in the background. According to Chen, this fusion is "the only thing I think of when I watch Moon Knight." RELATED: A Decade After Sailor Moon Debuted, Its Director Created a Far Less Popular Sports Anime      Based on the character created by writer Doug Moench and artist Don Perlin, Moon Knight premiered on March 30 and is the sixth television series in the MCU. The show stars Oscar Isaac as the titular hero, who is a mercenary who suffers from dissociative identity disorder. Other members of the case include May Calamawy, Ethan Hawke and Karim El-Hakim. The show's creative team includes writer Jeremy Slater (The Umbrella Academy), cinematographer Andrew Droz Palermo (The Green Knight) and director Mohamed Diab.  Moon Knight's story is heavily rooted in the culture of ancient Egypt, and those involved have made an active effort to stay as historically and mythologically accurate as possible. This careful attention to detail is notable in the wake of Diab's criticism of DC comic book movies, including Wonder Woman 1984, for their inaccurate depictions of the country and its culture. RELATED: Marvel Fans Are Convinced Moon Knight Dropped the MCU's First F-Bomb The original Sailor Moon manga series was published in Kodansha's Nakayoshi magazine from 1991 to 1997, producing 18 volumes worth of content. The story follows high schooler Usagi and her friends as they fight villains and prevent the destruction of the universe as the Sailor Guardians. The manga has a devoted fan following; over 35 million copies of the series have been sold globally.  The Sailor Moon manga was first adapted into an anime by Toei Animation in 1992 and has gone on to inspire a wealth of tie-in books, films, video and tabletop games, stage musicals and even an ice skating show. It has also spawned several theme park attractions; the popular Pretty Guardian Sailor Moon The Miracle 4D: Moon Palace Chapter attraction from 2019 is set to return as part of this year's Universal Cool Japan and will feature an extra scene. The first season of Moon Knight is currently making its debut on Disney+, and various entries in the Sailor Moon franchise are available to stream on Funimation, Crunchyroll, Hulu, Amazon Prime and Netflix. In 2021, she earned her PhD in Communication & Rhetoric from Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute and currently works in the Department of Communication, Liberal Arts, and Social Sciences at New Mexico Tech. Her research examines the linguistic structure of storytelling and pop culture. She can often be found marathoning horror movies instead of sleeping, playing puzzle games, and reading a probably unhealthy amount of fanfiction.  More                     From Hayley McCullough

https://www.cbr.com/goku-lessons-from-ve.Title: 10 Things Goku Can Learn From Vegeta
Data: www.cbr.com                  CBR Exclusives   Comics   Comics News   Comic Features   Comic Previews   Comic Reviews     Movies    Movie News   Movie Features   Movie Reviews     TV    TV News   TV Features   TV Reviews   Wrestling     Anime   Gaming   Lists   Write For CBR   More   CBR Forums   Buyer's Guides   Nerd Culture   Find a Comic Shop       Follow Us   Follow CBR            Something New                    	Covering the hottest movie and TV topics that fans want. Home Anime 10 Things Goku Can Learn From Vegeta    10 Things Goku Can Learn From Vegeta  By CBR Staff Published 11 hours ago     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email   If Goku could pick up on some of the qualities that Vegeta has, Goku could become just as powerful as any God of destruction.                  Goku and Vegeta have been friendly rivals since Dragon Ball Z, but Goku has always been the more relied upon fighter between the two. Goku may currently be the strongest fighter, but Vegeta has been making many strides to keep up with his rival counterpart as the series progresses.  RELATED: 10 Best Things About Goku Under Whis' tutelage paired with their constant encounters with stronger foes, Goku and Vegeta have had their work cut out for them. Whis has mentioned the flaws that each fighter possesses and points out that the two are strongest when fused together. If Goku could pick up on some of the qualities that Vegeta has, Goku could become just as powerful as any God of destruction.  10          Having A Sense Of Pride As A Saiyan                 Part of Goku's charm is that he doesn't carry the same level of pride as his warrior race, the Saiyans. By comparison, Vegeta's greatest asset as the "Prince of all Saiyans" is his incomparable pride of being one.  Goku learning more about the Saiyans' pride may make him a bit more boastful, but finding confidence in being a natural-born warrior may go a long way in his mentality when fighting. This sense of pride may help Goku take fights a bit more seriously.  9          Being A (Better) Role Model For Your Kids                 Fans of Dragon Ball would agree that Goku hasn't necessarily been around for a good portion of Gohan's youth. Whenever Goku showed up, trouble would soon follow. Vegeta on the other hand has grown to become a great parent and is looked up to by both present and future Trunks. RELATED:Dragon Ball Z: 10 Times Goku Put Himself Before His Family  Goku isn't winning any "Father Of The Year" awards compared to Vegeta's level of parenting. Vegeta is shown spending quality time taking care of the kids, and not all time spent with his son Trunks' training.  8          Having Original Attacks                 The Kamehameha and Solar Flare are some of Goku's signature attacks. Sadly, those abilities aren't his original moves. A lot of Goku's moves and abilities were taught to him by teachers he either sought out or ran into. For Goku to be the main protagonist, it's surprising that he doesn't have a move that he has created on his own.  Vegeta has a bunch of special moves, that surprisingly, Goku hasn't taken and made his own. From his famous Galick Gun to Big Bang Attack, Vegeta has mastered many moves that weren't taught to him by Gods or aliens.  7          How To Treat Your Wife                 Why Chi-Chi is still with Goku remains a mystery, but being married to the strongest warrior in the universe must have some perks. However, Vegeta has gone the extra mile and has shown multiple subtle displays of affection to his wife, Bulma, that Goku could take notes on. Vegeta and Bulma may not have started off on the right foot, but Vegeta has shown admiration for his wife's abilities and agitation towards anyone that would bother "his Bulma." Vegeta hasn't spent many years away from his family to train in the afterlife and has taken on babysitting the kids whenever his wife asked.  6          Vegeta's Fashion Sense If these two had to do a popularity contest based on style, Vegeta would win every time. Goku has been wearing the same orange gi since Dragon Ball. Dragon Ball GT finally gave him a new gi color, but the style was lacking compared to Vegeta's. The few times Goku has changed, the clothes wouldn't fit him very well, and he has mentioned that he doesn't feel comfortable in clothes that fit him. Maybe give credit to Bulma for Vegeta's trendy clothes, but Vegeta's style doesn't mind taking risks. Remember when Vegeta had a mustache?  5          Showing Respect To Higher Beings                 Goku has been on the verge of ending many lives by just being the whimsical martial artist he is. For someone that can read power levels and sense ki energy, Goku usually lacks formality towards gods and other higher beings that can easily wipe away existences. Vegeta, who is aware of the statuses and legends of these beings, always rolls out the red carpet. RELATED: 10 Times Goku Was Put In His Place In Dragon Ball Although his pride usually overshadows his judgment, Vegeta knows when to be quiet and respectful toward those higher in power. Especially when that power can wipe away or restore a universe. Vegeta provides many meals for Beerus and Whis just to keep the earth safe.  4          Taking Fights More Seriously                 Fans all know the feeling when the Z warriors are about to defeat the enemy, but Goku lets them power up again to turn the tide. Goku never takes his fights seriously until someone dies. He even played around with the likes of Kid Buu's destructive tendencies just to see the extent of his power. Vegeta was a victim of this mentality in the Cell Saga and dearly paid for it. Fast-forward to Vegeta's training with Whis, he has learned to fight at full power regardless of what level his opponent is. Goku has even been told by Whis that he would be stronger if he fought more seriously.  3          Know That All Evil Can't Be Redeemed                 Throughout the series, Goku has met a lot of opponents that later became friends or rivals. Most of his current friends were once conflicts that Goku has to deal with. However, there are some characters that are too evil to be kept alive and have no hope of turning over a new leaf. Vegeta is the opposite and will end an opponent's life without hesitation. Maybe if Goku had Vegeta's standards on what is evil, the majority of Dragon Ball's villains wouldn't be later threats or still trying to destroy the earth.  2          Utilizing Battle Tactics                 Whenever Goku gets into a fight, it's rare to see him thinking with his head. He fights instinctively and doesn't have much of a plan when facing tough opponents. Thanks to his friends and allies, Goku has managed to prevail over foes, but maybe fighting an opponent one-on-one isn't the best idea.  RELATED: 10 Things Goku Learned From Whis Goku could learn to fire a ki blast whenever an enemy has their back turned to him. Vegeta was the difference for shooting Cell in the back when Gohan was struggling against him. It's not fighting dirty, just strategy by catching your opponent by surprise.  1          Goku Can Learn To Be More Careful In Battles                 In Dragon Ball Super, Whis has pointed out Goku's weakness: he's too careless. Though some may describe Goku as more of a clear-headed individual, Vegeta is more of a careful and tactical fighter. Goku could benefit from Vegeta's way of thinking.  Goku letting opponents reach full power or thinking they will turn over a new leaf has gotten him and his friends into a lot of trouble. Vegeta didn't give a second thought to destroying Cooler, Frieza's brother. Maybe Goku should reconsider Frieza's threat level since his potential is so high. Goku and Vegeta have been friendly rivals since Dragon Ball Z, but Goku has always been the more relied upon fighter between the two. Goku may currently be the strongest fighter, but Vegeta has been making many strides to keep up with his rival counterpart as the series progresses.  RELATED: 10 Best Things About Goku Under Whis' tutelage paired with their constant encounters with stronger foes, Goku and Vegeta have had their work cut out for them. Whis has mentioned the flaws that each fighter possesses and points out that the two are strongest when fused together. If Goku could pick up on some of the qualities that Vegeta has, Goku could become just as powerful as any God of destruction.  10          Having A Sense Of Pride As A Saiyan                 Part of Goku's charm is that he doesn't carry the same level of pride as his warrior race, the Saiyans. By comparison, Vegeta's greatest asset as the "Prince of all Saiyans" is his incomparable pride of being one.  Goku learning more about the Saiyans' pride may make him a bit more boastful, but finding confidence in being a natural-born warrior may go a long way in his mentality when fighting. This sense of pride may help Goku take fights a bit more seriously.  9          Being A (Better) Role Model For Your Kids                 Fans of Dragon Ball would agree that Goku hasn't necessarily been around for a good portion of Gohan's youth. Whenever Goku showed up, trouble would soon follow. Vegeta on the other hand has grown to become a great parent and is looked up to by both present and future Trunks. RELATED:Dragon Ball Z: 10 Times Goku Put Himself Before His Family  Goku isn't winning any "Father Of The Year" awards compared to Vegeta's level of parenting. Vegeta is shown spending quality time taking care of the kids, and not all time spent with his son Trunks' training.  8          Having Original Attacks                 The Kamehameha and Solar Flare are some of Goku's signature attacks. Sadly, those abilities aren't his original moves. A lot of Goku's moves and abilities were taught to him by teachers he either sought out or ran into. For Goku to be the main protagonist, it's surprising that he doesn't have a move that he has created on his own.  Vegeta has a bunch of special moves, that surprisingly, Goku hasn't taken and made his own. From his famous Galick Gun to Big Bang Attack, Vegeta has mastered many moves that weren't taught to him by Gods or aliens.  7          How To Treat Your Wife                 Why Chi-Chi is still with Goku remains a mystery, but being married to the strongest warrior in the universe must have some perks. However, Vegeta has gone the extra mile and has shown multiple subtle displays of affection to his wife, Bulma, that Goku could take notes on. Vegeta and Bulma may not have started off on the right foot, but Vegeta has shown admiration for his wife's abilities and agitation towards anyone that would bother "his Bulma." Vegeta hasn't spent many years away from his family to train in the afterlife and has taken on babysitting the kids whenever his wife asked.  6          Vegeta's Fashion Sense If these two had to do a popularity contest based on style, Vegeta would win every time. Goku has been wearing the same orange gi since Dragon Ball. Dragon Ball GT finally gave him a new gi color, but the style was lacking compared to Vegeta's. The few times Goku has changed, the clothes wouldn't fit him very well, and he has mentioned that he doesn't feel comfortable in clothes that fit him. Maybe give credit to Bulma for Vegeta's trendy clothes, but Vegeta's style doesn't mind taking risks. Remember when Vegeta had a mustache?  5          Showing Respect To Higher Beings                 Goku has been on the verge of ending many lives by just being the whimsical martial artist he is. For someone that can read power levels and sense ki energy, Goku usually lacks formality towards gods and other higher beings that can easily wipe away existences. Vegeta, who is aware of the statuses and legends of these beings, always rolls out the red carpet. RELATED: 10 Times Goku Was Put In His Place In Dragon Ball Although his pride usually overshadows his judgment, Vegeta knows when to be quiet and respectful toward those higher in power. Especially when that power can wipe away or restore a universe. Vegeta provides many meals for Beerus and Whis just to keep the earth safe.  4          Taking Fights More Seriously                 Fans all know the feeling when the Z warriors are about to defeat the enemy, but Goku lets them power up again to turn the tide. Goku never takes his fights seriously until someone dies. He even played around with the likes of Kid Buu's destructive tendencies just to see the extent of his power. Vegeta was a victim of this mentality in the Cell Saga and dearly paid for it. Fast-forward to Vegeta's training with Whis, he has learned to fight at full power regardless of what level his opponent is. Goku has even been told by Whis that he would be stronger if he fought more seriously.  3          Know That All Evil Can't Be Redeemed                 Throughout the series, Goku has met a lot of opponents that later became friends or rivals. Most of his current friends were once conflicts that Goku has to deal with. However, there are some characters that are too evil to be kept alive and have no hope of turning over a new leaf. Vegeta is the opposite and will end an opponent's life without hesitation. Maybe if Goku had Vegeta's standards on what is evil, the majority of Dragon Ball's villains wouldn't be later threats or still trying to destroy the earth.  2          Utilizing Battle Tactics                 Whenever Goku gets into a fight, it's rare to see him thinking with his head. He fights instinctively and doesn't have much of a plan when facing tough opponents. Thanks to his friends and allies, Goku has managed to prevail over foes, but maybe fighting an opponent one-on-one isn't the best idea.  RELATED: 10 Things Goku Learned From Whis Goku could learn to fire a ki blast whenever an enemy has their back turned to him. Vegeta was the difference for shooting Cell in the back when Gohan was struggling against him. It's not fighting dirty, just strategy by catching your opponent by surprise.  1          Goku Can Learn To Be More Careful In Battles                 In Dragon Ball Super, Whis has pointed out Goku's weakness: he's too careless. Though some may describe Goku as more of a clear-headed individual, Vegeta is more of a careful and tactical fighter. Goku could benefit from Vegeta's way of thinking.  Goku letting opponents reach full power or thinking they will turn over a new leaf has gotten him and his friends into a lot of trouble. Vegeta didn't give a second thought to destroying Cooler, Frieza's brother. Maybe Goku should reconsider Frieza's threat level since his potential is so high. Data: www.cbr.com                  CBR Exclusives   Comics   Comics News   Comic Features   Comic Previews   Comic Reviews     Movies    Movie News   Movie Features   Movie Reviews     TV    TV News   TV Features   TV Reviews   Wrestling     Anime   Gaming   Lists   Write For CBR   More   CBR Forums   Buyer's Guides   Nerd Culture   Find a Comic Shop       Follow Us   Follow CBR            Something New                    	Covering the hottest movie and TV topics that fans want.
